channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: U.K. Inflation Slowed in January
item.description: The reading increases the chances of a rate cut by the Bank of England when policymakers next meet in March.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Hasn’t Taken Any Decision on Term
item.description: Comment comes after the Financial Times earlier cited an unnamed source in reporting that Lagarde would step down early.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: RBNZ Leaves Interest Rates on Hold, Expects Inflation to Soften
item.description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand left interest rates unchanged at its monetary policy meeting and said it expected inflation to retreat soon and for economic recovery to gather pace in the year ahead.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Fed’s Barr Wants Proof Goods Inflation Is Retreating Before Additional Rate Cuts
item.description: Federal Reserve governor said the job market might be “especially vulnerable to negative shocks,” given low levels of job creation and a low firing rate.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: There was a little less heat in Canadian consumer inflation to start the year than anticipated thanks to a sharp drop in prices at the pump
item.description: Consumer price pressures in Canada eased slightly in the first month of the year as prices at the pump fell sharply.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Fed’s Goolsbee Says Future Rate Cuts Depend on Inflation Progress
item.description: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee continued to express his view that policymakers could make several more rate cuts if inflation shows it is headed back to the Fed’s 2% target.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: U.S. Home-Builder Sentiment Edges Lower on Cost Concerns
item.description: Confidence among U.S. home builders inched lower this month, as affordability challenges persisted.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: New York Manufacturing Activity Expands Modestly
item.description: Factory activity in New York State continued to grow this month, albeit at a slightly slower pace than in January, with firms remaining optimistic as capital spending plans reached a multiyear high.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Ireland’s Goods Exports to U.S. Rose by 52% in 2025
item.description: The surge to €111.7 billion was driven by sales of pharmaceuticals, with Ireland now accounting for a fifth of all EU exports to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Jobless Rate Rises to Near Five-Year High
item.description: The 5.2% reading—combined with slowing wage growth—provides further incentive for the BOE to cut its key rate next month.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: January’s Gains Endure as High Supply Tempers February U.K. House-Price Growth, Rightmove Says
item.description: Property website Rightmove said U.K. house prices in February were virtually flat on month as a high choice of homes for sale and steadying buyer activity prevented a rise.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: Easier access to home loans and modular construction are among the options the House and Senate are weighing to battle high housing prices
item.description: Modular housing and easier access to home loans are among the proposals lawmakers are working on.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: The Trump administration is considering an overhaul of steel and aluminum tariffs that is in part likely to reduce levies on many consumer goods
item.description: The administration is weighing a plan to ease tariffs on some consumer goods while protecting U.S. companies facing overseas competition.
item.dc:creator: Bob Tita

item.title: Annual inflation slowed in January, falling more than economists expected, helped by declining prices for gasoline and used vehicles
item.description: While the reading was cooler than expected, consumers still saw higher costs for computers, ​appliances​ and hospital care.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kiernan

item.title: BOE’s Key Rate Is Too Low, But Answer Is Not A Rise, Says Chief Economist
item.description: Huw Pill said inflation can be squeezed out of the economy without a rise in borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Europe’s Exports to U.S. Rose Despite Tariffs, as Imports From China Jumped
item.description: Exports from the EU to the rest of the world increased 2% in 2025, while imports gained at a faster 2.4% pace.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Swiss Inflation Holds Steady
item.description: Annual inflation was unchanged at 0.1%, reinforcing expectations that the Swiss National Bank will keep rates on hold at its next meeting.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: BOJ Could Soon Declare Inflation Target Achieved, Hawkish Board Member Says
item.description: Bank of Japan policy board member Naoki Tamura floated the possibility that the bank could soon declare that its price target has been achieved, as the nation’s inflation is becoming stickier.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Home sales fell 8.4% in January, the biggest monthly decline since February 2022
item.description: Freezing temperatures and high home prices snuffed out the sales momentum from previous months.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: U.S. jobless claims fell last week as employers held onto their staff at stable levels.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: The mixed jobs picture reflects surging demand for people in healthcare and social services but a bleaker environment for government employees, factory workers and cubicle dwellers
item.description: From the Biden to Trump economies, healthcare keeps surging.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Demand for healthcare workers is outstripping all other sectors. That means big changes in a U.S. labor market where retail and white-collar hiring have stalled
item.description: Demand for healthcare workers is outstripping all other sectors. That means big changes in a labor market where retail and white-collar hiring have stalled.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: The government has dramatically lowered its estimates for how many jobs the economy generated over the past two years
item.description: Revised data Wednesday showed the U.S. economy generated far fewer jobs in 2024 and 2025 than was initially estimated.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: The U.S. added 130,000 jobs in January, surging past expectations
item.description: January’s job gains surged past expectations and marked a strong start to the year following a weak year of job growth.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Taiwan Exports Start 2026 Strong in Bright Sign for Economy
item.description: Taiwan’s exports hit the fastest growth since early 2010, as AI-powered demand continues unabated.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: The Trump economy in 2025 was a roller coaster, yet one thing remained constant: Americans are focused on prices. Here’s what a sampling of people across the spectrum have to say.
item.description: Some are living close to the economic edge; others are spending freely and seeing their wealth rise. But Americans of all stripes can’t stop talking about prices.
item.dc:creator: Jeanne Whalen

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Has Climbed in February, Michigan Survey Says
item.description: Consumer sentiment ticked up to 57.3 in February, according to a preliminary reading from the University of Michigan’s monthly survey, a positive signal that Americans’ economic mood is improving despite longstanding anxieties about inflation and the job market.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Industrial Production Declined at End of 2025
item.description: Production declined 1.1% overall in 2025, with economists expecting that to be the bottom of an industrial trough for Europe’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The resignation of Argentina’s statistics chief over delays in updating the inflation index has stirred up memories of price meddling
item.description: The resignation of Argentina’s statistics chief over delays in updating the inflation index has stirred up memories of price meddling.
item.dc:creator: Silvina Frydlewsky

item.title: Eurozone Retail Sales Sank at End of 2025
item.description: Sales fell more than expected in December, as the rebound in household spending that is expected to help the economy in 2026 remains fragile.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Without Immigrants, U.K. Economy Would Be Smaller, More Indebted, Says NIESR
item.description: The U.K.’s leading economic research body also said it expects inflation to settle at the Bank of England’s 2% target later this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Home builders are proposing new policies to the White House, looking for help to unload the biggest glut of housing inventory in 15 years
item.description: Companies are devising a plan for a federally backed “rent-to-own” program to help reduce the biggest surplus of homes in many years.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Irish Economy Soared in 2025 on Weight-Loss Drugs Boom
item.description: Ireland’s GDP was 12.6% higher on year, the fastest expansion since 2021, even as Trump raised tariffs on imports from Europe and urged businesses to bring their production to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Consumer Confidence Dropped to 12-Year Low in January, per Conference Board
item.description: The monthly survey’s primary index dropped from 94.2 in December to 84.5 in January as the economic mood worsened across ages and income levels.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Rocked by growth-sapping shocks, countries around the world are rolling out large fiscal stimulus packages financed by bumper budget deficits
item.description: Rearmament, an aging population, technological change and fear of voters are fueling a risky trend.
item.dc:creator: Tom Fairless

item.title: Business Activity Picks Up in Parts of Europe and Asia
item.description: Business activity in the U.S. and a number of large economies across Europe and Asia picked up at the start of the year, with signs of a rebound in export orders as the global economy adjusts to the increase in U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
